Official Website: http://squidsoft.net
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Humanity has just emerged from the lowest point in its collective history, and
the closest it has been to extinction since the advent of agriculture. By the
year 2304, the Coalition of humans and their alien allies the Jinu has spread
across the stars, and thought themselves powerful. But the Outsiders, an alien
empire occupying vast reaches of Rimward space, proved them wrong. First contact
between the two allies was severed, and suddenly humanity was alone. Then the
Outsiders attacked in force, and human planets and governments fell one by one.
                         It was the apocalypse.
But contrary to the beliefs of many, not all hope was lost. After five years,
a single starship, the Percival Lowell, returned from Rimward space, bringing
with it the means to nullify the Outsiders' greatest weapon. With this, and the
help of many other brave pilots, the occupying Outsiders were driven off human
               worlds and back to where they came from.
 Humanity is now trying to rebuild, and trying to regain what it has lost. The
Outsiders are finished with occupation, and now desire only to see humans
extinct.
New threats and new mysteries seem to appear every day. In the midst of it all,
civilian starships span the stars, maintaining an open threat against any new
       invasion and trying to make a few credits while they're at it.
You too have felt the lure of this; the desire for a unique freedom that most
citizens will never know, the drive to explore, the need to defend your species,
         and yes, greed for the vast wealth that is to be had.
                   It is time to take to the stars.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Welcome to the original and still the most innovative pulp science fiction
multiplayer roleplaying adventure!
Originally opened in its classic form on 19 December 1998! Reopened in its new
iteration on 28 February 2009!
All original work (including setting, non-player characters, design, source
code, all related background material, and all text) located in this game or on
the Squidsoft.net website is copyright (c) Squidsoft.net 1998-2015. Unauthorised
reproduction prohibited.
Warning: Speech in this game is largely uncensored, and sensitive individuals
may find some other players offensive. The staff is ultimately not responsible
for the words and actions of the players.
The last server reset was at Thu Aug 25 17:51:20 2016 UTC
We're on Twitter! @StarConquest for server status notifications and out-of-game
contact!

web address.

    * Welcome to Star Conquest! *
[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a glossy sapphire blue ceramic felo chow bowl, a small yellow ball
containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a small seashell pink trash can, a
white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard and filmy deep purple
hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft periwinkle cashmere blanket,
a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle bed pillow, and a hand-made
purple and amethyst flower quilt on it, a large oval dark purple and light
purple cloth rug, a small oval turquoise rattan table with a glass top, and
Samantha the large violet felo here.
You can go out.
(You are lying on a white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard
and filmy deep purple hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft
periwinkle cashmere blanket, a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle
bed pillow, and a hand-made purple and amethyst flower quilt on it.)

[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters Block]
You see a large round light purple and dark purple cloth rug, a violet leather
sectional sofa, an antique oak table from Old Earth, a textured plasteel floor
lamp with a cream shade (casting a white-colored glow), a dusky pink rattan
cabinet, a wall-sized bubbling coral pink-lit aquarium containing blue and
yellow aquatic life and multicolored round rocks, a small bubbling neon blue-lit
toroidal aquarium containing blue and red aquatic life and round rocks, a
wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing light violet and blue
aquatic life and sea green and neon blue round rocks, a small orange ball
containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy pale pink ceramic felo
chow bowl, a small purple trash bin, Xavier the big silver soldier felo, and a
Tardick lizard named Asteria here.
You can go north, east, south, west, up, and down.
go shower
[Starship "William Dove"; Shower]
You can go out.
start
You push a small button, starting the shower. Hot water begins to pour over your
skin. You feel cleaner already.
A metallic silver metachannel FTL communicator beeps quietly, indicating that it
has unread notices.
Hot, steaming water continues to bathe every inch of your skin, cleansing you as
it invigorates your senses.
read comm
You glance at your communicator's screen.
Notice from the Voice of the Corps: Good day AEU! The current state of the Corps
After 17 days since the current term began, so far, the AEU has completed 13 out
of 82 total decoy beacon drops, or 15.85 percent. The AEU is responsible for 0
out of 12 total destroyed RATS nests, or 0.00 percent. The AEU is responsible
for 1 out of 1 total salvage ops, or 100.00 percent. [15:47 26 August 2316 GST]

relaxed. Steam floats lazily in the enclosed space.

ftl accord
The ship is already moving.
ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
Via general sector communication, Accord of Free Worlds Command transmits,
"Hello, Shooting Star. Welcome to Accord space."

Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

Star! Welcome to home space!"

l
[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a purple photocopier, Purr the humanoid service robot, a
round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a clear plastic food storage
container, and a high tech silver star print holovid here.
You can go south and out.
(You are sitting on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white
and sapphire star quilt on it.)

[New Earth; Piper Wincott Memorial Garage]
Even though this starship garage smells like machine oil and heavy lubricants,
it is spacious and well-lit. Massive hydraulic systems raise and lower starships
to and from the landing pad above, and technicians and mechanics in silvery gray
coveralls ensure that everything keeps running smoothly. A well-lit stairway
which leads to the pilot's lounge is here.
You can go up.

l
[Starship "Chemeketa"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a wormhole drive tracer here.
You can go up and out.
(You are lying down.)
Via general sector communication, Aenea transmits, "Hello there, Chemeketa!
Welcome to home space!"

[Endymion Spaceport; Landing Pad]
It is night-time here, the roughly circular landing pad lit only by several
small spotlights mounted around the edges of its rough concrete surface. With
the exception of sprawling warehouses to the east and southwest, the buildings
here are of sun-bleached adobe, with darkly tinted glass at the small square
windows. Beyond the spaceport is the desert. The night sky is filled with stars,
with a brilliant curtain of shifting lights stretching across the north.
The two-person bolt thrower "Danube", the two-person bolt thrower "Ready, Aim,
Fire", the two-person tugboat "Chemeketa", and the four-person space constructor
"Under Construction" are landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine and a trash can here.
You can go north, northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, west, and
northwest.

[Revo Developmental Technologies; Main Lobby]

[Endymion Spaceport; Landing Pad]
It is night-time here, the roughly circular landing pad lit only by several
small spotlights mounted around the edges of its rough concrete surface. With
the exception of sprawling warehouses to the east and southwest, the buildings
here are of sun-bleached adobe, with darkly tinted glass at the small square
windows. Beyond the spaceport is the desert. The night sky is filled with stars,
with a brilliant curtain of shifting lights stretching across the north.
The two-person bolt thrower "Danube", the two-person bolt thrower "Ready, Aim,
Fire", the two-person tugboat "Chemeketa", and the four-person space constructor
"Under Construction" are landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine and a trash can here.
You can go north, northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, west, and
northwest.

collected a great many of them."

in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

ftl drydock
A lone outpost glitters in an otherwise nondescript cloud of debris.
The League's legendary shipyards hang motionless in the dark here. Once, the
stations would be all but glowing with waste heat as the Intersector
Shipbuilding Company rolled out ship after ship. Now the stations are still and
darkened, and the ISC is no more.
A large frame hangs in space here, sufficiently large to at least contain a
battlecruiser-class starship.

voice, "Detecting vessel 'Under Construction.' Welcome to Capital Ship Drydock."

bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

[Beacon C-09; Docking Bay]
Illuminated panels inset into bare metal walls cast a dim glow over this austere
docking bay. The air is cool, the gravity light. The only item of interest is a
wide hatch surrounded by various black and yellow warning signs and the exterior
mechanisms of an emergency locking system.
The two-person tugboat "Chemeketa" and the one-person flitter "Wreckage II" are
landed here.
You can go up and down.
u
[Beacon C-09; Computer Room]
You can go up and down.
rd
I don't understand that.
l
[Beacon C-09; Computer Room]
A slender white tower occupies the center of this room, extending from floor to
ceiling with green and blue lights blinking regularly in tall recessed panels
along its length. Beside the tower is a smaller unit with rounded convex sides,
a plaque on a blinking status display labeling it as the inert fluid cooling
system. There is no sign of the heavy bundles of cables that link the powerful
computer to the rest of the housing, but spaced regularly along the white tiled
floor and walls are several maintenance hatches.
You can go up and down.

w/ the beacon."

l lily
Lily Kaise
She appears to be 27 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
abdomen is attractive and punctuated by a cute navel. Her face is oval and
pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are lovely and blush
pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth. Beneath a set of
arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her waist-length,
straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall of loose curls
down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled crimson dragon pierces her belly button, a small enameled
cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe, and a small enameled cerulean
blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.
 She is wearing a close-fitting mystic purple cropped top, a pair of tight white
denim jeans with a small dark-red 'XX' embroidered on the back left pocket, and
a pair of mystic purple suede clogs. She is also wearing an orange and white
blessed prayer bracelet around her wrist, a slender bracelet of tiny tinkling
silver bells around her wrist, a neon purple wrist-mounted chronometer, a solid
silver ring engraved with dragonflies, a delicate ring of silver wire and small
purple amethyst crystals, a metallic gold touch einrophone in a metallic purple
reinforced plastic phone holster, and a soft fuchsia Tardick lizard snuggly
labeled 'Asteria'. Her head, face, both eyes, neck, both elbows, abdomen, both
forearms, both wrists, and both hands are left uncovered.
She is carrying nothing.

help org
--
Star Conquest Help: Organizations
--
Category: Game Systems
--
An organization allows a group of pilots to organize in a semi-official manner.
Pilots in an organization can:
 * Share funds for the purposes of buying organization-owned starships.
 * Contribute to a group insurance fund to cover the destruction of
organization-owned starships.
 * Have their own communicator channel.
 * Cooperatively operate temporary space stations.
 * Support large starships.
TYPES OF MEMBERS
 * Founder: There is only one founder. This is the person who created the
organization. One must have 1000 aggregate points in order to found an
organization.
 * Acting Founder: If the organization's founder plans on taking a leave of
absence, they can appoint somebody to temporarily stand in as founder of the
organization. Alternately, if the founder (or current acting founder, for that
matter) is inactive for an extended period, a trustee may request the
appointment of a new acting founder. Until the acting founder steps down or the
founder unilaterally revokes their access, they will be treated as the founder
in every way, and the actual founder's vote will be similar to a trustee's.
 * Trustees: These are people with a higher level of trust, with the ability to
propose and vote on organization actions, and buy starships and station modules
on behalf of the organization.
 * Members: Regular members can contribute to the organization and use
organization-owned ships.
REQUIREMENTS
The organization, just like an individual pilot, will gradually build up
industry, combat, and other types of points as its members work. In order to buy
a ship or a station module, not only must the trustee meet its requirements, but
the organization must as well.
Members can decide which percentage of their points they are contributing, from
0% to a maximum determined by the size of the organization, most often 10-20%.
UNITY
Organizations are free to take in any member they like belonging to any
alliance. However, once more than one alliance is involved in an organization,
unity is taken into account.
Unity affects both the rate at which an organization earns points, and the total
amount of points it has. Organizations with low unity (for instance, when its
members are at war) are very ineffective.
The more alliances you bring into your organization, the more unity will affect
it. Extremely large organizations will also suffer from disorganization, which
increases unity penalties. The most effective organization will be one
consisting of a few like-minded characters who have banded together for good,
well-roleplayed reasons.
MANAGING AN ORGANIZATION
Organization rooms are present in every capital spaceport. You can manage your
organization with the MENU command, or view its information with the INFO
command.
Organizations may choose to list themselves publicly and offer open recruitment.
You may go to your capital's organization room and apply to any organization
that has done this.
Organizations are also encouraged to use the in-game message board and other IC
means to recruit new members. Recruitment and other organization business should
NEVER occur outside of the game.
ACTIONS
Trustees can initiate and vote on certain actions that affect the organization
as a whole. The action will pass as soon as the "for" votes create a majority,
or fail as soon as an "against" vote makes a majority impossible.
The founder, however, can act as a dictator. Actions initiated by the founder
will be immediately approved. Additionally, the founder's vote will instantly
pass or veto a pending action.
ORGANIZATION POINTS
Organizations gain points much as pilots do. They do this when members that have
chosen to contribute points perform point-gaining activities.
To contribute points to your organization, visit your capital's organization
room and choose the Change Point Contribution Level option. Depending on the
size of your organization, you may set your contribution level to 5%, 10%, 20%,
or even up to 100%. This is the percentage of points that you will "lose" to
your organization. In other words, if your contribution level is 20% and you
gain 10 points from a load of salvage, you will keep 8 points while 2 points go
to your organization.
When an organization has 1000 industry points and 500 space combat points, it
can begin earning command points by contributing certain modules (salvage
processors, salvage op controllers, battle analysis scanners, and certain
others) to temporary space stations. Command points open up unique opportunities
for an organization to assist its alliance, generally with better station
modules.
ORGANIZATION FACILITIES
Each capital spaceport contains a pilot liaison office, and within this office
is an entire level devoted to organizations. This level has its own organization
management center as well as more specific facilities for both business and
pleasure. Organizations can choose to purchase access to these facilities.
STARSHIP SUPPORT
As you may be aware, an alliance sometimes limits the total number of starships
of certain models, particularly gunship- and cruiser-class ships. This is
because an alliance's funding is limited, and starships incur a constant cost in
energy, replacement parts, and routine maintenance performed by spaceport
technicians. Thus, for example, you may wish to buy a cruiser, but find that
your alliance is unwilling to construct and support any more.
However, this can be solved if your organization chooses to take up these costs
instead. Organizations can take over the costs of supporting starships, and
thereby, they can allow starships to be operated beyond the alliance's limit.
Every Conquest period, each starship's support cost will be deducted from the
organization's support fund. If the organization cannot cover its support costs,
flight control will deny launch clearance for the affected ships.
Note that, as of this writing, it is not of any benefit to support ships which
are produced in unlimited numbers. Also, it's important to note that this
affects only the maximum number of available starships, not the rate at which
they are constructed.
VASSALIZATION
Organizations with at least 2000 command points can become "thanes" of less
advanced organizations. "Thane" is an archaic word for one who is able to levy
resources from his or her vassals, but is otherwise not much elevated above
them. Vassalization should not be considered a punitive relationship or a
leadership hierarchy, but rather simply a way to more efficiently distribute
resources.
An organization can offer vassalization to a more advanced organization of the
same alliance, offering to pay 25%, 50%, or 75% of all station part costs in the
form of megacredits. In return, the vassal organization will be counted as a
full contributor on all stations that the thane organization is involved in.
This allows, for example, for a new or less advanced organization to pay for
half of the cost of an expensive salvage op controller module that it cannot buy
on its own, and then be counted as a full and equal contributor towards the
finished station.
In order for a vassal to pay anything, its percentage must work out to be a
whole number. For instance, 25% of a 1-megacredit station core is not a whole
number, and the vassal would not be able to pay anything.
Vassals gain by receiving credit for station activities, and thanes gain by
reducing their own, often much greater costs. This also allows for more
organizations to be involved in a single station. It will also allow
organizations of the same alliance to essentially ally with each other and work
together more closely.
Vassals must designate a certain number of megacredits to be usable by their
thane. Their thane cannot spend more than this amount. Vassals also have full
control over the relationship with the option to unilaterally withdraw
vassalization at any time.
Thanes have a togglable option to use vassal megacredits at all. If a thane
organization wishes to be the sole contributor to a station, it can toggle the
option off. While the option is on, all vassals will contribute their portion of
the station part cost. In the event that there are enough vassals contributing
enough to completely pay for the part, the thane organization will pay nothing.
If there are enough vassals to exceed the part's total cost, the highest
contributing vassals will be prioritized. Thanes can unilaterally remove vassals
at any time.
It is up to the organizations and their members to decide under which
circumstances they might offer, accept, and withdraw vassalization. Again, on
the face of it, the relationship is nothing more than a system of resource
distribution that acknowledges the thane organization's greater access to
advanced station parts and the past effort that was required to gain it.
ORGANIZATION REGULATIONS
Organizations may make whichever rules or regulations they like in regards to
who they accept as members, required contribution levels, whose starships they
will support, and so on. The game's staff will generally not help you enforce
these individual regulations; however, the organization may enforce them itself
in any manner which does not run afoul of the game's policies.
Strange, extreme, or unusual organization rules or actions may have in-character
consequences, as with anything else in the game.
ORGANIZATIONS AND ROLEPLAYING
Organizations are a good way to bring varied groups of people together and have
them engage in either conflict or friendship beyond the usual alliance lines.
Organizations should be a way to meet new people and experience the world with
friends and like-minded characters. Organization-wide endeavors make excellent
fodder for unique events organized by the game's staff.
An organization should strive to avoid becoming insular and isolated from the
rest of the game, and they should not be used as a shortcut to bring out-of-game
relationships into the roleplaying environment. An organization provides you
with another identity for your character and another way in which you can affect
the game world; it should not become a bubble which insulates you from everyone
else's roleplaying.
Additionally, a player should never be cajoled to join or abandon an
organization via out-of-game communications, nor should organization actions be
planned outside of the game. That sort of thing always does massive damage to
the game's roleplaying environment, and it will not be tolerated.
POLICY STATEMENT
Organizations make it easier to get around alliance and point requirements for
starships in a way that is difficult to enforce automatically. That much is
obvious. So in place of that, we'll explicitly state our intentions for how the
system is meant to be used. Working against these intentions in order to avoid
alliance/point requirements WILL be a violation of the Workarounds policy
(Policy 6).
 * Organizations are intended to consist of people who are friends or who at
least wish to actively cooperate. Organizations should not exist purely as
business transactions or as some sort of starship exchange. Additionally, nobody
should ever be paid to found, join, or leave an organization.
 * Members of an organization are expected to remain members on a semi-permanent
basis. Members should not be joining and leaving an organization very quickly,
and especially not joining multiple organizations within a short period of time.
 * Trustees are expected to remain trustees on a semi-permanent basis. Trustees
WILL NOT be promoted just long enough to buy a ship, and then demoted. Other
players WILL NOT be paid or otherwise cajoled to join an organization and become
a trustee just long enough to buy a new ship for it.
 * Again, organizations should never plan or recruit outside of the game. This
is covered in greater detail under Policy 9: Metagaming.
--

Hello Johann and Sean,
First please don't share the information below with others as this
is not a planned expedition.
I need to go out to the Aquarium to get a shell for my org. I am
limited on time to be able to be awake to fly my platform for the
better part of each day and my window is up around September 5th so
I need to allow for enough time to travel to and from prior to
then. in order to plan for enough time, I should leave no later
than Monday, August 29th. and preferably over this coming weekend.
Having said this, I want to invite a few to come along and we can
share the eggs. I have all of the varieties of fish but I do want
to claim one of the dark gray snapper eggs. The rest would be up
to the crew to share. I might get another Seastar if I see a color
I don't have though.
If either or both of you would like to come along with Shule and I
and perhaps a couple of others, please let me know what day/time
from after 2359 on Friday, August 26th on until Monday latest.
We'll be flying my Exploration Platform, William Dove. There are
crew quarters available for 4 additional persons besides Shule and
myself or 4 couples as it can accomodate ten crew. However I'm
not particularly interested in taking along 8 more crew. If you
have someone in mind you would like to invite, if they're not going
to room with you, bear in mind that we may have to get organized as
to who rooms where if they are not a part of a couple.
As for Shule and I, we're generally able to fly from about noon GST
until around 0500 the next day but sometimes as late as 1400 on.
We'd like to keep flying so if either you or Sean are typically
awake from around 0500 until 1300, that would be very helpful but
not required. I generally just reduce trim while sleeping so we're
still moving.
Let me know and if you have any thoughts, concerns or whatever.
Best regards,
Lily Kaise

read last cream
--
Shule. Here is the report I promised you. I hope at the very least it makes it
so that the League doesn't catch you by surprise.
First, the meeting point. IF you are able, meet at the torus, with a secondary
meeting point at Earth if the Torus is inaccessible. Crew large ships first,
then small ships if we are able. Let the larger ships take care of larger
targets, and smaller ships take care of smaller targets. I know it's possible to
beat a larger ship with a smaller, but it's more efficient this way.
The largest ship in the sector has command of the fleet and if they tell a
smaller ship to do something, the smaller ship should listen.
IF two or more ships are engaging the same target, don't go to where the enemy
has just been, or you will open yourself to friendly fire. I know it's not
always possible, but try to stay on different z-axis coordinates than your
allies, that will avoid unnecessary blockages and could cause ships to get hit.
I would like to see this done with all the alliances and have designated z-axis
points for each, but I seriously doubt I can get everyone to go along with that.
If the enemy is an ifs fleet, please refer to the posts about ifs priority on
this board. If you are fighting ifs, it is best to have two or more larger ships
to take turns taking the lrl damage.
I would love to have invasion drills, but my previous attempts to implement them
have been unsuccessful, however, the better prepared we are, the harder it will
be for us to be subjugated again.
--

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
+m'p3ncv+^d!]q$Hh@Q)i7:\y9]b8J,RI&_wk'lU
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.

are people too!"

Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The mist swirls and obscures your vision. It quickly evaporates, leaving you in
an alien landscape. Tall grassed plains stretch on as far as the eye can see, as
the planet's sun is slowly setting on the horizon.

out

red.

use cannon
You raise a bulky asteroid supply cannon to your eye and begin carefully aiming
at the asteroid's surface through the scope.
(14 seconds roundtime.)
After a few careful seconds aligning everything in the scope, it flashes the
okay to fire. You pull the trigger and an anchor shoots rapidly from the barrel
of a bulky asteroid supply cannon! You lift off the asteroid's surface slightly,
landing as the anchor finishes securing itself.

at a single-use asteroid anchor through the scope.

[General Communication] Rogue Romano transmits, "The hell?"
Greetings Johann,
I appreciate the report you sent me detailing the League's defence plan. There
are some very good points, but I also have some questions.
First of all, I like the idea of using the Torus as a staging point. It is the
most heavily armoured station and doesn't seem to be attacked often. The capital
planets as a second staging point also makes sense.
I do, however, have some questions. In the event of a large invasion, how many
ships and what class of ships do you envision as an ideal response? Also, if we
respond with more than one of the largest ships in the sector, e.g. two or more
cruisers, who has command of the fleet? 
In terms of actual combat, I think if we place too many limitations, we may
cause pilots to lose their concentration thereby risking ships and their crew.
Having fought in wasps launched from a morningstar, I know it can get cluttered.
However, if I have to consider that I can't move certain places because of the Z
axis I've been assigned, that extra  second could result in my ship
unnecessarily getting hit as well as limiting my options in terms of were I can
move. I do, however, think it is a good idea to pair big ships with small ships
and attack the same ship. For example, a gunship and a destroyer attacking the
same ship could be very useful and efficient. In fact, that destroyer could just
follow that same gunship around, attacking everything it does. Those are my
thoughts so far. I look forward to receiving your comments and thoughts as well.
Regards,
*
*
*
*
*
*
Shule
*
.
--
Greetings Johann,
I appreciate the report you sent me detailing the League's defence plan. There
are some very good points, but I also have some questions.
First of all, I like the idea of using the Torus as a staging point. It is the
most heavily armoured station and doesn't seem to be attacked often. The capital
planets as a second staging point also makes sense.
I do, however, have some questions. In the event of a large invasion, how many
ships and what class of ships do you envision as an ideal response? Also, if we
respond with more than one of the largest ships in the sector, e.g. two or more
cruisers, who has command of the fleet? 
In terms of actual combat, I think if we place too many limitations, we may
cause pilots to lose their concentration thereby risking ships and their crew.
Having fought in wasps launched from a morningstar, I know it can get cluttered.
However, if I have to consider that I can't move certain places because of the Z
axis I've been assigned, that extra  second could result in my ship
unnecessarily getting hit as well as limiting my options in terms of were I can
move. I do, however, think it is a good idea to pair big ships with small ships
and attack the same ship. For example, a gunship and a destroyer attacking the
same ship could be very useful and efficient. In fact, that destroyer could just
follow that same gunship around, attacking everything it does. Those are my
thoughts so far. I look forward to receiving your comments and thoughts as well.
Regards,
Shule
--

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at Comet Surface.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a black plastic tray of spider chow, a small oval
turquoise rattan table with a glass top, a clear plastic food storage container,
and a high tech silver star print holovid here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go up and out.

your suit, you hear the hiss of air quickly leaving the airlock.
You wrap your arms around Lily Kaise, pulling her close.
out

use cannon

After a few careful seconds aligning everything in the scope, it flashes the
okay to fire. You pull the trigger and an anchor shoots rapidly from the barrel
of a bulky asteroid supply cannon! You lift off the asteroid's surface slightly,
landing as the anchor finishes securing itself.
use cannon
You raise a bulky asteroid supply cannon to your eye and begin carefully aiming
at a single-use asteroid anchor through the scope.
(34 seconds roundtime.)
The scope flashes the okay to fire. You pull the trigger and a ribbon shoots
from the barrel to automatically secure itself to a single-use asteroid anchor
with an attached line.

use cannon
You raise a bulky asteroid supply cannon to your eye and begin carefully aiming
at a single-use asteroid anchor through the scope.
(42 seconds roundtime.)
The scope flashes the okay to fire. You pull the trigger and more ribbon line
shoots out to automatically secure itself to a single-use asteroid anchor with
an attached line. It quickly spools itself up, tensioning tightly over your
ship. Hopefully it will hold.

cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
Lily Kaise just entered the ship.
The computer announces, "Cycling complete."

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a black plastic tray of spider chow, a small oval
turquoise rattan table with a glass top, a clear plastic food storage container,
and a high tech silver star print holovid here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go up and out.
Lily Kaise presses a button to deploy the ship's anchor.
A sharp crack is heard throughout the ship as the anchors on either side deploy
with explosive force, biting deep into the surface of the asteroid.
remove helm
You remove a gold spacesuit helmet from your head.
The ship's engines fire, and the anchored asteroid gradually begins to move
toward AEU Asteroid Processing Nuclear Message Beacon.
The computer reports that the asteroid is approximately two sectors from its
destination.

As the asteroid falls into the station's collection bay, your ship detaches and
heads for the docking bay.
You receive 36,397,204.59 AEU credits for this asteroid!
Your income is deferred until the temporary station's storage module is
transferred to a spaceport.

"RockIt!". The organization has earned 2,914,884.57 credits.

l
[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at Metal-rich Asteroid Surface.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a black plastic tray of spider chow, a small oval
turquoise rattan table with a glass top, a clear plastic food storage container,
and a high tech silver star print holovid here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go up and out.
Lily Kaise squeezes you affectionately.
Lily Kaise sits down on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with
thick gold fringe.
Lily Kaise removes a plain white spacesuit helmet from her head.

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a black plastic tray of spider chow, a small oval
turquoise rattan table with a glass top, a clear plastic food storage container,
and a high tech silver star print holovid here.
Lily Kaise is sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow.
You can go up and out.
out

help ace
--
Star Conquest Help: Aces and Veterans
--
Category: Background
--
In Star Conquest, we have a few levels of pilots beyond your standard pilot.
* Ace pilots are well known by most, if not all pilots in the leagues, and their
actions have been recorded in the annals of history, such that anyone with a
vested interest in the pilot leagues would know of their deeds.
* Veteran pilots transcend the ace classification, in that they tend to be
'larger than life'. A veteran pilot tends to be well known in popular (non-pilot
and otherwise) culture, and more often than not have holovids detailing their
exploits.
Obtaining ace or veteran status is handled primarily ingame, through one's
character's actions, although in some cases it can also be obtained through a
special application in character generation.
The following is a listing of current and former (player character) pilots
holding ace or veteran status.
AEU:
* Ather Jammoa: Ace Pilot
    Status: ACTIVE
    Notable Awards: Phoenix Burst (Medal), Accord of Free Worlds Meritorious
Service Medal, Aria Star (Medal)
    Achievements: Defense of New Earth, Defense of United Stations of the Accord
* Sean Dillon: Retired Former Ace Pilot
    Status: INACTIVE
    Notable Awards: Velourian Star (Medal)
    Other Notes: Acedom removed due to mishandling of delicate diplomatic
situation.
League:
* Alfred Wecksly: Ace Pilot
    Status: ACTIVE
    Notable Awards: Silver Coalition Command Flying Cross
* Nissi Valdaire: Ace Pilot
    Status: ACTIVE
    Notable Awards: League Distinguished Flying Cross, Accord of Free Worlds
Meritorious Service Medal, Aria Star (Medal), Purple Heart (Medal)
Fringe:
* Cesar Ysidro: Ace Pilot
    Status: ACTIVE
    Notable Awards: Burlingame Siegebreaker (Medal)
    Achievements: Defense of Chetumal
    Other Notes: Participant in [CLASSIFIED] Experiment #009703: [CLASSIFIED].
* Darin Frost: Ace Pilot
    Status: INACTIVE
    Achievements: Blockade Runner/Smuggler
    Other Notes: Location unknown.
* Nick Enderton: Ace Pilot
    Status: INACTIVE
    Achievements: Defense of Chetumal
    Other Notes: Location unknown.
* Rowan McKell: Former Veteran Pilot
    Status: INACTIVE
    Achievements: Defense of Chetumal
    Other Notes: Demerited by Nina Thomas for repeatedly speaking ill of the
Confederation of Fringe Worlds.
* Scott Hawkins: Former Ace Pilot
    Status: ACTIVE
    Achievements: Defense of Chetumal
    Other Notes: Former member of the Fringe Navy. Acedom removed, reasons
unknown.
* Tabi Canis: Ace Pilot
    Status: ACTIVE
    Notable Awards: Accord of Free Worlds Meritorious Service Medal
    Achievements: [3 CLASSIFIED ENTRIES], Defense of Chetumal
    Other Notes: [CLASSIFIED]
* Tony Matos: Retired Veteran Pilot
    Status: INACTIVE
    Achievements: Defense of Chetumal
    Other Notes: Lost vision during the Battle of Chetumal, Participant in
Fringe Medical Experiment #001719: [CLASSIFIED]
Mutuality:
* Anfisa of Marzore: Veteran Pilot
    Status: ACTIVE
    Notable Awards: Accord of Free Worlds Meritorious Service Medal, Aria Star
    Achievements: Defense of Sector -1: Renegade Fleet Command Center
    Other Notes: Member of unreg subfactions: Renegade, Marzore Clan, Shade
Clan, Former name: Aradi.
* Dylan Sparks: Ace Pilot
    Status: ACTIVE
    Achievements: Defense of New Beginning
    Other Notes: Member of unreg subfaction: Renegade. Custom made. Location
known.

[Space Station "Helios"; Service Corridor]
This wide, dimly lit corridor, its convex grey metal walls undecorated but for a
few warning signs relating to explosive decompression, runs below the main
passageway between the original station and the Stardock. Though the corridor
above is often crowded with travelers, this corridor is mainly for the use of
technicians and dock workers loading starships with supplies bought in the
Stardock.

[Space Station "Helios"; Starship Storage]
The Helios starship storage facility runs the entire length of the original
station. Most of the space is occupied by powered-down starships, their dark
hulls reflecting the dim overhead lights. At each end of the garage are the
enormous automated hydraulic hoists that transport the ships to and from the
docking bays above. A downward stairway leads to a small alcove containing a
salvage op controller facility.
You can go north, south, and down.

The computer announces, "Two."
The computer announces, "One."
The computer announces, "Skim subroutine initialized."
You feel the deck underneath you shudder violently, and you stumble slightly.
The shuddering finally settles down.
The computer announces, "Skim initialization complete."
The computer announces, "Skim complete; starship has arrived at journey
destination."
ftl new
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Celestial
Explorer! Welcome to home space!"

ftl chetumal
What was once a feature of interstellar geography is now the name of an
alliance, and the heart of Fringe space can be found past this gateway. The tiny
station of Nuevo Laredo stands guard here.
The planet of Chetumal floats before you here, the richest planet among the
Fringe Worlds, although that isn't saying a lot.

[ChetuMall; South Concourse]
This spacious concourse is designed to accommodate throngs of shoppers. The
floors are tiled in shiny gray marble, and the pale gray walls are decorated
with advertisements and posters framed in vibrant purple and yellow. Here and
there are potted green Chetumalian ficus trees growing in filtered sunlight
streaming down from tinted skylights high above. On the south side of this
section of the concourse is the main entrance to the mall, an impressive arch
with tall sparkling clean transparisteel doors.
You see an automatic teller machine here.
You can go east, west, and out.

l
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers" and a
wormhole drive tracer here.
You can go south and out.
s

You can go north.

You put down an antique red birch table from New Earth.
l table
an antique red birch table from New Earth
The red birch of this deceptively simple four-foot-long rectangular antique
table is finely grained and highly polished to make the subtle variations in
color stand out. In the New Earth Colonial style, the legs are slim and straight
but arch gracefully into underside braces for the table top. The table top
itself has been left undecorated, the better to show off the beautiful grain of
the wood.
There is nothing on there.

[Chetumal City; New Rowan Veer]
A long white warehouse along this sidewalk has been subdivided into a number of
stores. Young trees in wooden planters and clumps of flowers in stone pots grow
at intervals along it, a nice contrast to the white cinder block of the
warehouse. Here, you see entrances to Violetta to the east, Dressed to the Nines
to the southeast, and The Cheshire Cat Diner to the south.
You can go north, east, southeast, south, and southwest.

power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Celestial Explorer, you are given
launch clearance under the AEU-Fringe non-aggression pact."
ftl new
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Celestial
Explorer! Welcome to home space!"

a blueberry rattan pantry cabinet

in blueberry stain and buffed to a soft shine. The sides, doors, and interior
shelves are made of strong, tightly woven color-washed wicker, and burnished
brass fittings accent the doors.

fan, a large white dinner plate, a large white dinner plate, a large white

plastic tray of spider chow, a Mutuality standard ration box, a Mutuality

y

A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Greetings, Celestial Explorer. The
Mutuality welcome you to this free port."
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.
out
You scramble to your feet.
out
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container here.
You can go out and enter into the ship.
You exit the ship.
[Space Station "Tandem"; Docking Bay Alpha]
The luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer" is landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine and a personal hoverpallet here.
You can go east and down.

enter celestial
You key in a transport of Celestial Explorer to your location.
The luxury sightseer "Celestial Explorer" is slowly brought in aboard an
automated flatbed, then lowered to the floor.
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container here.
You can go out and enter into the ship.
enter celestial
[Starship "Celestial Explorer"; Control Room]
You see a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers" and a
wormhole drive tracer here.
You can go south and out.
launch
The navigation systems are nonfunctional until their power is restored.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Celestial Explorer, you have been
given clearance to launch.
ftl gateway
The ship is already moving.
ftl gateway
The ship is already moving.
ftl gateway
ships
There are no other ships in the sector.
trace
No recent FTL drive traces detected.
Via general sector communication, Resistance Headquarters transmits, "Celestial
Explorer, be advised that the Free Port Doctrine is in effect here."
move
AutoStar detects 30 possible destinations.  Assembling destination list.  Please
wait.
--
AutoStar (general-purpose starship autopilot) Version 9.1
--
Destinations in this sector:
   Space Stations:
[1] Resistance Headquarters             
   Quantum Skim Accelerators:
[2] Quantum Skim Accelerator to The Cross
[3] Quantum Skim Accelerator to The Arm 
[4] Unlinked Quantum Skim Accelerator   
   Debris:
[5] Debris (nearest)                    
--
Enter your destination:
[Type a line of input or `@abort' to abort the command.]
2
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: Quantum Skim
Accelerator to The Cross.
Would you like autopilot to take the starship through this quantum skim
accelerator?
[Enter `yes' or `no']
y
You feel the ship shudder slightly as it approaches a quantum skim accelerator.
The computer announces, "Initiating connection with The Cross's local quantum
skim accelerator network."
The computer announces, "Connection established. Communicating between quantum
skim acceleration gates now."
The computer announces, "Skim subroutine initializing in five seconds."
The computer announces, "Four."
The computer announces, "Three."
The computer announces, "Two."
The computer announces, "One."
The computer announces, "Skim subroutine initialized."
You feel the deck underneath you shudder violently, and you stumble slightly.
The shuddering finally settles down.
The computer announces, "Skim initialization complete."
The computer announces, "Skim complete; starship has arrived at journey
destination."
ftl farport
Via general sector communication, Farport Station transmits, "Celestial
Explorer, be advised that the Free Port Doctrine is in effect here."
move
AutoStar detects 26 possible destinations.  Assembling destination list.  Please
wait.
--
AutoStar (general-purpose starship autopilot) Version 9.1
--
Destinations in this sector:
   Space Stations:
[1] Farport Station                     
   Debris:
[2] Debris (nearest)                    
--
Enter your destination:
[Type a line of input or `@abort' to abort the command.]
1
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: Farport Station.
Would you like to request docking clearance for Farport Station?
[Enter `yes' or `no']
y
You notify flight control of your desire to dock.

Mutuality welcome you to this free port."
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.

l
[Farport; Precision Glyph Transfer Facility]
This is a cluttered room of bare metal with various diagrams and blueprints hung
on the walls. Many of these images depict alien glyphs. Terminals on wheeled
carts, thick cables, crates of equipment, and workbenches form a sort of
obstacle course across the length of the room. Technicians walk here and there,
working at the terminals and taking notes in the endless pursuit of new
knowledge. Tall stepladders are available, providing access to the upper heights
of suits of powered armor.
You can go northeast.

l
[Farport Level 2; Corridor]
The aroma of cooked food fills this dimly lit corridor, and from behind the thin
doors come the sounds of voices raised in conversation. Each door has a name on
it, some printed neatly, others scrawled in nearly illegible letters. Between
the doors, someone has painted nearly the entire corridor in waves of neon
colors. Up and down among the waves are numerous drawings. At the end of the
corridor is a maintenance hatch.
You can go west.

l bag
a red nylon mesh shopping bag
This red shopping bag is made of stretchy nylon mesh. It has a matching
synthleather band around the top, with two flexible handles for easy carrying.
Square patches of velcro on the handles keep the bag closed when necessary.
It is open.

halves, a can of chunk pineapple, a can of chunk pineapple, a can of ravioli, a

hot coffee dispenser, Jewel the large violet glowing felo, a Tardick lizard
named Asteria, and Buddy the hefty blue soldier felo here.
You can go north, east, south, west, up, and down.

You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, Purr
the humanoid service robot, and a purple photocopier here.

[Starship "Shooting Star"; Control Capsule]

sit

launch
The navigation systems are nonfunctional until their power is restored.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Shooting Star, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."

[The Torus; The Arboretum]
Between the windows on each side of this section of corridor are two arches
perhaps twenty feet high, each one containing a small green tree with lacy
leaves. The trees grow from beneath the floor, their slender, dark brown trunks
emerging from decorative circular grates. While most of the illumination here is
provided by the lighted walls, tiny star-like lights twinkle from the boughs of
the trees. Three doorways on the outer side of the corridor lead to small shops,
one selling souvenirs, the second identified by a brightly lit twinkling sign as
'Holiday Ornamentation,' and the third named 'The Ontological Felo,' which has
articles of oddly shaped clothing in a small display window next to the doorway.
You can go northeast and southwest.

Subject: Re: salvage, hopefully final discussion for a bit
Author: Ted Warburton
Posted: 12:55 26 August 2316 GST
--
I am greateful for all the work that is done on this, for the experiments and
the work involved in stations. For new pilots, I really do feel that a points
paying salvage site is crucial, so it sounds like 134 and 285 are important in
different ways to me.
--

FTL Interalliance Communications Network
--
Subject: Re: salvage, hopefully final discussion for a bit
Author: Morris Corlew
Posted: 13:03 26 August 2316 GST
--
I guess the biggest difference, as I've tried expelling out here, and can still
make points faster at 134, if it were up, is for newer pilots who can't get a
grapple that will do grade 40-60 debris like what is at 285. I understand the
issues brought up about dead batteries, sleeping pilots, things like that. It is
definitely a valid point. But I already miss 134. It's nice to be able to
salvage in a sector that I don't find a roid in, but 134 was much easier and
less time consuming for the points. Could I go out there on my own? Yeah, I
could. But without an accelerator, the time spent traveling both directions so I
can drop one load at a local salvage station more than makes up for the time I'd
save on the shipwrecks out there.
--

Subject: Re: salvage, hopefully final discussion for a bit
Author: Kim Saunders
Posted: 15:09 26 August 2316 GST
--
Hi,
there are a big number of sectors with debris in it connected to the beacon
network. Maybe it's worth trying salvaging in them and see what they are like.
Belt of orion is but one of them, the entire tesla pipe is filled with debris,
every alliance has sectors with debris. Battle of mir only has grade 0 and 10
shipwrecks, only small ones and 1 per sector, it's not great I admit.
If after a while it turns out that missing 134 is a big issue, we can revisit
this and I would be willing to make modules available to set up at least a
beacon and accelerators, but let's try a little while without it first?
Good luck with the continued experiments.
Kim
--

l
[The Torus; Dock Beta]
The pale gray walls, floor, and ceiling of this massive EAOS docking bay glow
with a pale white light. Though the bay remains open to space, it somehow also
retains its atmosphere. Outside, against the starry expanse of space, you can
see the bright glint of a solitary blue-white star. A sign indicates that the
main concourse is to the west, and the doorway to a rare starship supply store
is to the south, but it has been closed and securely locked.
The vostok-class capsule "Faster Than A Speeding Bullet!" is landed here.
You can go west.

[Starship "Shooting Star"; Control Capsule]

enter shooting
Board what?
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Shooting Star, you are given undock
clearance under the AEU-EAOS non-aggression pact."
ftl new
The ship is already moving.
ftl new
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
move
The starship is already moving.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
move

wait.

AutoStar (general-purpose starship autopilot) Version 9.1
--

[2] Space Station Alpha

Enter your destination:
[Type a line of input or `@abort' to abort the command.]
1
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: New Earth.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Shooting
Star! Welcome to home space!"
Would you like to request landing clearance at New Earth?
[Enter `yes' or `no']
y
You notify flight control of your desire to land.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Hello, Shooting Star. We read your AEU
transponder. You are cleared to land at the city of New Phoenix."
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.
out
out
You exit the capsule.

[New Earth; Piper Wincott Memorial Garage]
Even though this starship garage smells like machine oil and heavy lubricants,
it is spacious and well-lit. Massive hydraulic systems raise and lower starships
to and from the landing pad above, and technicians and mechanics in silvery gray
coveralls ensure that everything keeps running smoothly. A well-lit stairway
which leads to the pilot's lounge is here.
You can go up.

[Starship "William Dove"; Airlock]
You see a large secure xenology storage container, a row of flightlockers, a rug
woven of large dark green fern fronds, a glossy seashell pink ceramic felo chow
bowl, a luxuriously soft oval amethyst rug with a gold fleur-de-lys in the
center and thick gold fringe, a personal hoverpallet, a small mystic purple
bioplastic crate, and Shasta the big onyx soldier felo here.
You can go out and enter into the ship.
enter dove
[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, Purr
the humanoid service robot, and a purple photocopier here.
You can go south and out.
l couch
a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and sapphire star
quilt on it
Contoured to evenly absorb and redistribute weight from the stress points of a
human body, this smooth black, densely cushioned couch is broad and long enough
to lie on.
On top of it you see a hand-made white and sapphire star quilt.
l
[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, Purr
the humanoid service robot, and a purple photocopier here.
You can go south and out.
l table
a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top
Washed with white stain for a softly gleaming finish, this round rattan coffee
table has an unbreakable glass top supported by open arches of medium-weight
rattan.
On top of it you see an elegant purple glass vase containing a dozen red roses,
a small hot coffee dispenser, a small hot tea dispenser, a fresh fruit juice
dispenser, a tiny statue of a fiery orange and gold dragon spreading its wings
over Feng Wo Station, a globe of New Earth on a bronze base, a small fragrant

quilt on it
Contoured to evenly absorb and redistribute weight from the stress points of a
human body, this smooth black, densely cushioned couch is broad and long enough
to lie on.

[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport
Landing Pad.
You see a glossy sapphire blue ceramic felo chow bowl, a small yellow ball
containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a small seashell pink trash can, a
white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard and filmy deep purple
hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft periwinkle cashmere blanket,
a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle bed pillow, and a hand-made

[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
The busy landing pad of New Earth's capital city's spaceport sits over a large
bay at the tip of the southern continent. The pad itself is a huge square sheet
of white plasteel surrounded by gleaming new starship service structures. On the
southern side of the pad is a circular structure with wide transparisteel
windows affording a fabulous view of the ocean. A softly lit sign over the
transparisteel doorway reads, 'Pilot Lounge,' and a separate doorway is marked
'Liaison Office.' It looks like you can GO into either of those places. To the
west, a bridge spans the gap between the landing pad and the rest of the
spaceport.
The three-person clipper "Obliteration" and the two-person light transport
"Registered Merchant 155" are landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine and a small trash can here.

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at Centauri Spaceport; Landing Pad.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
purple photocopier, and Magellan the arachnoid security robot here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go south and out.
(You are sitting on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white

[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
The busy landing pad of New Earth's capital city's spaceport sits over a large
bay at the tip of the southern continent. The pad itself is a huge square sheet
of white plasteel surrounded by gleaming new starship service structures. On the
southern side of the pad is a circular structure with wide transparisteel
windows affording a fabulous view of the ocean. A softly lit sign over the
transparisteel doorway reads, 'Pilot Lounge,' and a separate doorway is marked
'Liaison Office.' It looks like you can GO into either of those places. To the
west, a bridge spans the gap between the landing pad and the rest of the
spaceport.
The five-person A.S.S. tactical platform "William Dove" is landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine and a small trash can here.
You can go north, south, west, and down.

leaving you in a dim silence.

charged.

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
purple photocopier, Magellan the arachnoid security robot, a blue plastic food
storage container, Lucky the little calico CatBot, Mandy the old hefty indigo
feathered felo, Desiree the little black and white spotted CatBot, and Kiska the
humanoid service robot here.
Kim Saunders is sitting on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch.
You can go south and out.
(You are sitting on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white
and sapphire star quilt on it.)
l kim
Kim Saunders
She appears to be 19 years old. She is about five feet and six inches tall and
has tan skin. Her body is of average build with attractively curved hips and
attractive calves. She has rounded shoulders and slightly larger than average
breasts. Her face is round and somewhat pretty, with an average nose and dimpled
chin. Her lips are full and applied with red lipstick, and occasionally part to
reveal a set of slightly yellowed teeth. Pink blush is applied to her cheeks.
Beneath a set of lightly-colored eyebrows, her eyes are green and wide, and
enhanced with two-shade shimmery green eyeliner. Her mid-back length, slightly
curly hair is dark blonde and parted on the side and smoothed back behind her
ears. She has neatly trimmed painted glittery silver fingernails. She has a
large black satin bow in her hair. She has a tiny birthmark on her neck.
 She is wearing a long-sleeved cream silk blouse with a round neckline, an
expensive silver watch with diamond accents, a flowing sapphire silk skirt, and
a pair of strappy light green high-heeled sandals. She is also wearing a light
purple cotton drawstring purse, a metallic green touch einrophone in a black
leather phone holster, a delicate ring of silver wire and small pink quartz
crystals, a delicate blue crystal necklace, and a wrist-mounted chronometer. Her
head, face, both eyes, neck, left wrist, and both hands are left uncovered.
She is carrying nothing.
A metallic silver metachannel FTL communicator beeps insistently as it receives
a new notice.

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
